body: The failing test is [testCacheOpAfterQueryCancel](http://files.apachegeode-ci.info/builds/geode-pr-2311/test-results/distributedTest/1534096152/classes/org.apache.geode.cache.query.dunit.QueryMonitorDUnitTest.html#testCacheOpAfterQueryCancel) in QueryMonitorDUnitTest.  I'm having trouble recreating the failure on my local machine, but seems to be a timeout problem on line 423 in QueryMonitorDUnitTest when awaiting server 3 (line 311/333 in QueryMonitorDUnitTest).  Any suggestions of what to look closer at would be much appreciated (especially since the original PR #2220 didn't have a issue with this test)
Its likely just a flaky Test. Push an empty commit to your branch to kick off another CI run. If the Test passes open a ticket for the flaky Test.
It seems to have passed, so I've opened up [GEODE-5568](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-5568) in Jira.

Seems fine since we've integrated the PR checks with concourse.  Let's leave the travis jobs in place for geode-examples and geode-native though.

LGTM.
It looks like this change increased the test runtime by about 10 minutes, but it dropped the load average from ~300 to ~100, which seems more reasonable for a fully loaded 96 core machine.
@smgoller @rhoughton-pivot
This PR builds off of #2313
@upthewaterspout What does it look like if we split the difference. A 10m increase isn't great in my mind and means we are leaving some CPU on the table.

I'd rather err on the side of not overloading the system. The fact that we halved the number of processes and only increased the total runtime by 20% means we were definitely overloaded before. Tracking down issues related to an overloaded machine wastes time for everyone. A load average of 100 seems like a pretty reasonable target for this size of machine.

I think we need to make changes to the test framework to allow tests to pass without environmental influences. If I was to run this same test on my laptop currently with other tests or under any load it would likely fail because of the production default timeout values of the cluster. These failing tests are not testing cluster stability but some feature that presumably lacks the ability to be tested without a cluster. Allowing the cluster to be stable under load does not effect the outcome of these tests.

Increasing runtime of the overall testing and CI negatively impacts the development life cycle. With this change we are clearly throwing away CPU cycles. We should give back that time to the developers by making the framework more forgiving to load.

You have made a single change and observed a favorable result with single test. I can get favorable results with the 95% reproducibility based on repeated runs. It is not unreasonable to try a more scientific method and repeat this change multiple times to see if the favorable outcome is 100%, then try different values.

I noticed significant duplication in `test.gradle` with respect to the other test targets and have streamlined and unified that configuration.  If that seems beyond the scope of this ticket, I'm happy revert that last commit and make it its own ticket / let it be subsumed in the future work to remove `FlakyTest` as a whole.
@smgoller @metatype Can you review this? I want your take on the new image contents/dockerfile as well
I'll buy off on this change if we can plan to evaluate it's success rate, and if we have no timeout, we make adjustments to get some time back.
Seems legit.

One more data point - 36 parallel containers added maybe 5 minutes, although it's hard to say because the stddev of the runtime is probably greater than 5 minutes. It had a load average over 200.

Another interesting data point - the total amount of time spent in tests. This is a bit of a measure of how much time we causing tests to wait, although there is other noise in here.
 - 48 containers - 24.75 hours
 - 36 containers  - 19.75 hours
 - 24 containers - 15.5 hours
@PurelyApplied please remove the last commit or add a block to add the flaky exclusion back. This change will result in the remaining flaky tests being executed in the CI.

I don't think it is unreasonable for have some subset of distributed tests to have timing related checks that will fail under heavy load. I prefer that it not be the norm. If some subset of tasks "needs" less load, then identify those and we can break them out into another job. We can try not to punish the whole development/test loop for the sake of a few bad actors in the test suite.

@rhoughton-pivot  - Just to be clear, this is not a subset of the tests. This is a product membership-timeout we are hitting. That affects *all* DistributedTests. I also think if we are hitting that timeout, that is a sign that we are seriously overloaded; it essentially means we couldn't do the equivalent of ping in something like 15 seconds.
I hadn't noticed that we got rid of the `FlakyTest` box in our pipeline.  That's awesome!  But yes, that does mean those tests aren't getting run elsewhere.
@PurelyApplied the changes to the submodules seems to be negatively impacting the integration tests. Let's decouple those changes from this issue please.

Since you had to update nearly every project to fix this logging issue maybe it makes more sense to make `geode-core` a compile dependency on `geode-dunit` and then excluded it on the old versions testing explicitly. I think it makes more sense to have the common path be the easy path.
One alternative might be allowing membership to use longer timeouts in distributedTest, except where we're actually testing things to do with membership timeouts.

Test failures in Integration and Distributed are known flaky tests:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-3778
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-4883
@upthewaterspout @WireBaron @galen-pivotal Could you all review this pull request?
failures unrelated to this PR.

@pivotal-jbarrett The integration failure appears to be due to a bad commit on / test-merge against `develop`.  See https://concourse.apachegeode-ci.info/teams/main/pipelines/develop/jobs/IntegrationTest/builds/257.
Closing to approach this problem from a different angle

I love how much more readable this is! 

Part of me wishes that the concurrency rule was exposing a fluent interface, but I guess that would make the `add()` method clunkier.
@upthewaterspout @pivotal-jbarrett Here is the dependency change for unit-test compilation

If this is really just to make devBuild work, we should make the devBuild depend on these things, not classes.

The classes target is supposed to compile the production source. It's weird to have production source compilation depend on test source compilation.

@upthewaterspout Perhaps it is odd to have `classes` depend on test sources, but we already do this for all of the acceptance/ui/integration/distributed/upgrade/performance test sources. I'm literally making them all behave the same.
What are all the new *-test modules for?  I also don't understand creating empty test classes that just extend a base class.

We are trying to untangle the project dependencies between tests. Gradle
makes us jump hoops with syntax to get it working, and intelliJ doesn't do
well with our tricks

On Wed, Aug 15, 2018, 18:03 Anthony Baker <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> What are all the new *-test modules for? I also don't understand creating
> empty test classes that just extend a base class.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/2334#issuecomment-413388580>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/Aer30rvdaRBFvc6OaSQYSV0PCZ85tekTks5uRMTtgaJpZM4V-pNX>
> .
>

Some people seem to like extending test cases and when that is done across modules or test types then the base class must be shared. A base class is extracted and moved to the test module and a test class is created to extend it and run from the Test sources. 

The other opinion is to stop this practice of extending Test classes.

@upthewaterspout this is for `build` too, not just `devBuild`. Gradle doesn't build `testClasses` unless you do a `check`, which by default `build` does. It doesn't not build `*TestClasses` until you explicitly invoke `*Test` task. This would result in builds that didn't attempt to compile tests and potentially missing compilation failures as a result. The goal of these changes and dependencies it to assure that all "builds" invoke `compile*TestJava`.
@nabarunnag @jhuynh1 What's the hold up on merging this pull? it was approved 13 days ago and you are both committers.
@PurelyApplied @jinmeiliao What's the hold up on completing this PR? It has been open since the end of May.

It looks to me like a source set defined by the Facet plugin automatically gets added as a dependency of `build`.  Can you check that?  If so, I don't these adding any of the `compile*TestJava` tasks as a dependency of `classes` is necessary and just adds complexity.

I would keep the dependencies of the `devBuild` task completely separate.

It's not just about devBuild. We (Jake and I) disagree with Gradle that
'assemble' or 'compile' should not compile the test Java code, our change
ensures that all test sources are compiled as part of any life cycle task
that performs compilation

On Wed, Aug 15, 2018, 21:08 Anthony Baker <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> It looks to me like a source set defined by the Facet plugin automatically
> gets added as a dependency of build. Can you check that? If so, I don't
> these adding any of the compile*TestJava tasks as a dependency of classes
> is necessary and just adds complexity.
>
> I would keep the dependencies of the devBuild task completely separate.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/2337#issuecomment-413419462>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/Aer30vqtyL4gH0VstnZpTqxxpZ8VIP03ks5uRPBMgaJpZM4V-zM7>
> .
>

I ultimately don’t care where tests hang in gradles wack-a-doodle lifecycle. What must happen is that when a developer thinks they are compiling all targets that all targets should be compiled and that wasn’t happening with the facets. Now it may have been something else in our overly complicated gradle or the fact that all the tests depended on each other but the bottom line is that when theses lines were added it was to restore expected behavior. 

I’d like us to merge this request to restore expected behavior and then open an issue to re-evaluate these dependencies and life cycles once all the inter and intra projected test dependencies are resolved.

So if the idea is that extracting shared test utilities, fixtures, etc into a `*-test` submodule is necessary  because that's the best way to integrate with IntelliJ then sure let's do it (even though the additional complexity is annoying).  

I suggest sharing this idea on `dev@geode` so everyone is aware of this pattern and uses the test submodules correctly.

I think you should take the extra step to review and correctly factor any extended test classes.  I'm not in favor of creating artificial, empty subclasses.

Example:  perhaps the right choice for `ExportLogsDUnitTest` is to move `geode-web/src/distributedTest/java/org/apache/geode/management/internal/cli/commands/ExportLogsOverHttpDistributedTest.java` into geode-core until we can properly break out gfsh and geode-web.

Another example:  `extensions/geode-modules-test/src/main/java/org/apache/geode/modules/session/TestSessionsBase.java` is only used by classes in `extensions/geode-modules-tomcat7/src/integrationTest/java/org/apache/geode/modules/session/Tomcat7SessionsJUnitTest.java`.  Why move that?  Seems like it belongs next to it's subclasses since it isn't shared.

There are a dozen ways to skin this cat and we are 90% complete with this way. Anyone is welcome to refactor further if they think there is a better approach. This approach takes the path of least resistance to correct a wrong. By no means I am claiming this to be the best approach, just better than what we have.

Once complete there won't be any inter or intra project test source dependencies so the pattern will become painfully obvious. The pattern was also discussed in a thread between Kirk and I last week.

Please refactor any tests you don't like and if you can delete the shared test project in the processes even better.

`ExportLogsOverHttpDistributedTest.java` can't be in `geode-core` because it has build and runtime dependencies that `geode-core` does not and should not have.

`TestSessionsBase.java` is used by both tomcat 6 and tomcat 7 modules.
If it makes you feel any better. I just tested and a default import of the project into IJ works. No more disabling the module per source set.

How about making each subprojects' assemble task depends on these compile tasks then?

That would also make sure that things like 'Geode-core:build' will compile the integration test source.

Anyway,  I'm ok with merging this because it's not making things worse,  but I think since we noticed this problem this might be a good time to clean it up.
@aditya87 Sorry for not getting back to you sooner. Would you be willing to rewrite `GeoCoder` to not copy comments from Redis and be just an implementation of the public domain algorithm?

I think hooking to `testClasses` would be consistent with the typical Java lifecycle.  Why do we want to deviate from that?

As I said before, the Facets plugin already adds new source sets to `build` so the test classes *do* get compiled.  Check out this dry run with the explicit dependencies removed:

```
› gradle -m :geode-core:build -x test | grep compile | grep Test
:geode-core:compileAcceptanceTestJava SKIPPED
:geode-core:compileTestJava SKIPPED
:geode-core:compileIntegrationTestJava SKIPPED
:geode-core:compileDistributedTestJava SKIPPED
:geode-core:compilePerformanceTestJava SKIPPED
:geode-core:compileUiTestJava SKIPPED
:geode-core:compileUpgradeTestJava SKIPPED
```

I'm asking "why" because I want to have a simple, default build with no unnecessary customization.

My vote:  -0

You're right, I chose poor examples.

I agree with the approach in general.  I'm still unabashedly sad to see new empty test subclasses.

Facets adds them to `build` but `build` in Gradle means to do EVERYTHING, including running the tests. So its not a 'simple' build line if you end up turning off tasks you don't like.

We deviate so that `assemble`, which means to compile my code, will compile the test sources, which are also code.
But why not hook `testClasses` into `assemble` then?  How far down the path of "fixing" the gradle lifecycle do you want to go :-)

Would it be possible to clean this PR up? It currently has 23 commits and I think 22 of them are not about this stat fix. Instead they are about the ThreadMonitoring work which belongs to another pull request. I will go ahead and review the change in the 23rd commit but please clean this one up. You might want to just start with a new PR based off of develop.
Me too. Next story will make you less sad.
@dschneider-pivotal  is this ok to merge now?
@jujoramos maybe we replace Atomic with LongAdder... Which have been proven to be faster and more thread friendly than the Atomics..
@galen-pivotal Yes, I can do that. Thanks!
All tests have passed.  Pushing these changes.
@pivotal-jbarrett @smgoller @PurelyApplied

As a followup to this PR I'd like to see us converge on a single maven publishing plugin.  Originally the standard gradle plugin didn't support signing pom files.  We need that in order to publish release artifacts so that's why we used nexus.  Hopefully that's been fixed and we can converge on the newer one.
Did the pom customizations in the `modifyPom` configuration of `publish.gradle` get applied?
@galen-pivotal Made the requested changes.
I believe `modifyPom` is a nexus plugin thing only.
Have you compared the pom generated by nexus vs the maven plugin?  Are the dependencies exactly the same (including optional)?

Do we have any data showing that the contention for the stats monitor is sufficient to warrant using more memory?  `Adders` work by essentially allocating multiple `Atomic` cells to reduce contention across threads.  IOW, you only see faster performance on _contended_ writes.

@metatype, you are correct in stating that `Adders` and `Atomics` characteristically are the same under lower contention. Looking at the code, the contention could be minute and we _should_ have little to no contentions. The fact that the memory growth of the `Cells` within the `Adder` will only grow with high write contention, means that under low contention, the number of cells are small and memory overhead less significant. BUT, under higher contention is out performs Atomics, and for me the future proofing, without any extra effort is more beneficial.
They are definitely not. Good catch!
@FSOUTHERLAND @rhoughton-pivot @dickcav

CI failures for flaky tests.

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-5601
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-5602
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-5603

@jujoramos My understanding of these classes is that the updates to their values come from the single statistic monitor thread that also writes the statistics to a the .gfs stat archive. But I could be wrong about this. @galen-pivotal created the original GEODE-5314 ticket and he may know of how multiple threads can update these classes. I think @kirklund has more knowledge of these classes so it could be helpful to get his input.
If they are used concurrently then I don't think atomics, adders, and/or concurrentMaps would solve all the concurrency issues. The way the old value in the map is used to decrement the atomic and then later the new value is used to inc the atomic and update the map seems to need to be done all in one "transaction". The easiest way to do this and know the code is safe would be to do this all under synchronization. You should only introduce concurrent structures if you need to optimize concurrent writers. You could also do the reads under synchronization but I could see how that would have performance concerns if you have multiple readers or don't want a reader to be blocked by a writer. I think that might be what led the code to use volatiles originally. Kirk or someone else might have a better handle on how these classes are used.

@jujoramos @dschneider-pivotal @galen-pivotal Darrel is correct -- there is only ever one dedicated sampler thread which mutates the fields in these monitor classes, so there's no need to change the volatiles.
I think it would be helpful add a comment to these classes explaining how they are used and why they use volatiles.
It looks like the pom files generated for nexus are actually incorrect (they include test dependencies), while the POM files generated by the maven publish plugin should now be correct.
Can you post the diff between the 2 poms?  That would make it easier to review if the changes are correct.

Have you reviewed the effect this will have on the POM?  Can you post that as a comment?

Right now I'm -1 based on what appears to be broken pom dependencies.  For example, geode-cq *must* expose a dependency on geode-core.

[diff.txt](https://github.com/apache/geode/files/2303485/diff.txt)

Here is the diff of the POM files for geode-core

[diff-depends.txt](https://github.com/apache/geode/files/2303645/diff-depends.txt)
Here is a diff of just the dependencies and their scope.
Can I get a quick review? @boglesby @pivotal-jbarrett @upthewaterspout @PurelyApplied
I'm fine with removing dependencies with scope `test` from the pom.  We need to preserve the `optional` element though.
This branch still has some issues.  No point in reviewing this PR until they're fixed.

@metatype since we lack a really good external test its hard to tell if the pom changes are going to be an issue downstream. One change that seems odd is that changing dependencies from runtime to runtimeOnly resulted in a change of dependent jars as seen by the integration test that tests jars. Do you know if we really need to be shipping with dependencies on commons-codec and lucene-analyzers-phonetic? See https://concourse.apachegeode-ci.info/builds/19626 for the failure.
@metatype this should be ready to roll. The distributed tests are failing for out of memory again.

Yep, the dependencies on commons-codec and lucene-analyzers-phonetic are required and should be on the runtime class path.

It makes sense that changing to a runtimeOnly dependency would break this (it's the equivalent of provided).
Ready for review: @pdxrunner @upthewaterspout @WireBaron
@rhoughton-pivot @smgoller For your review.

@metatype changing deps to runtimeOnly is inline with the upcoming Gradle 5.0 changes and results in the maven POM showing the deps correctly as runtime scoped. The maven plugin shows 'runtime' dependencies as compile scoped otherwise.
Thanks for clearing up my misconception around `runtimeOnly`.
All the checks are green. I can pull this in now.

+1 to Darrel's comment -- if this must be used from a single thread, that should be clear from reading the class.

I'm eager to understand Geode's threading model better. @dschneider-pivotal / @kirklund Which one thread accesses this?

A single thread exists that wakes up at the statistic sampling interval and samples all the stats, writes them to the stat archive (if one is configured) and notifies listeners of changes (like these mbeans).
I think the main body of this thread is: org.apache.geode.internal.statistics.HostStatSampler.run()
@metatype take a look at the latest changes that correct the dependencies as they go into `geode-assembly` and the test for changes to jars.
@smgoller @rhoughton-pivot
Unfortunately the set of geode jars in the lib/ dir seem wrong when compared to our previous release (not the versions, but missing / incomplete).  I would also compare the manifest class path.
I think we will write some new tests for asserting the more strictly the contents of the assembly that will require some explicit intervention to allow new or removed files.
@metatype https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/2359

Hello @dschneider-pivotal,

I've reworded the javadoc, hope the message is clearer now.

> Also have you looked at these diffs? It seems like some methods that didn't really change just got moved to a different part of the file. Would it be possible to move them back so that the actual changes you are making would be more evident? Given that you have gone back to volatiles it would be nice if the diffs of the changes only showed things you are actually changing.

I moved the methods and attributes around following to this pattern: attribute declarations, getters and setters, constructors, protected and private methods, public methods, inner classes. I' aware that this is just a matter of preference and that currently the `spotless` plugin doesn't take into consideration these patterns, but I'd prefer to keep the order this way, it makes the classes easier to read and maintain. Either way, I can revert them back so only the actual changes are shown in the `diff`, just let me know.
A full pipeline deployment went green on `staging`, excepting categoric failures on `Windows*Test` jobs due to existing iteration against that infrastructure.
